description: From French laïque, from Latin laĭcus (“common people”), from Ancient Greek λαός (laós). Doublet of lay.

adjectives.description: laic (comparative more laic, superlative most laic)

entries.meaning: Lay, relating to laypersons, as opposed to clerical.
examples: And in conclusion it reflects to the disrepute of our ministers ... [that] they should still be frequented with such an unprincipled, unedified and laic rabble, as that the whiff of every new pamphlet should stagger them out of their catechism and Christian walking.

entries.meaning: A layperson, as opposed to a member of the clergy.
